snippet.textDisplay: I have King Size Pillowcases that I want to cut down to Regular size.   Guess what??? The excess fabric is 20" X 8" times 2 sides!!!  I can make 2 masks from each pillowcase.   I have vacuum cleaner bags that I can use for the inserts ( 4 layer Charcoal Hepa Filtration).
snippet.textOriginal: I have King Size Pillowcases that I want to cut down to Regular size.   Guess what??? The excess fabric is 20" X 8" times 2 sides!!!  I can make 2 masks from each pillowcase.   I have vacuum cleaner bags that I can use for the inserts ( 4 layer Charcoal Hepa Filtration).

snippet.textOriginal: When you talk about using a filter, are you talking about coffee filters or something else?

snippet.textDisplay: What is best to put in the pocket? I've read that vacuum bags filter too tightly and just encourage air to leak in from the sides. BTW, I have to be in and out of a medical center for my radiation therapy, so I use always use a cloth mask. Someone outside the medical field gave me an N95 mask with good intentions. But these masks are really made for use around aerosol virus particles, which are generated overwhelmingly in the special condition of ventilation machines, i.e., in hospital setting. It's why these masks are essential to ALL hospital workers w cases of COVID-19. I think I should donate it to my oncologist.  ?
snippet.textOriginal: What is best to put in the pocket? I've read that vacuum bags filter too tightly and just encourage air to leak in from the sides. snippet.textDisplay: Clothesline is also at Walmart. For the nose wire, I’ve seen some people use pipe cleaners, twisty ties from bread, metal clasps from coffee packages, and the loopy part of those hair clips that you bend to secure in place. You should probably ask to make sure these materials are ok if you’re making them for others, though.
snippet.textOriginal: Clothesline is also at Walmart. For the nose wire, I’ve seen some people use pipe cleaners, twisty ties from bread, metal clasps from coffee packages, and the loopy part of those hair clips that you bend to secure in place. You should probably ask to make sure these materials are ok if you’re making them for others, though.

snippet.textDisplay: Hi Brie, I wanted to thank you for putting out this tutorial video.  We have made three of these masks (quite easy) and they work tremendously.  We did not get the filters because they weren't going to arrive until the end of June.  These masks at least make us feel like we are not spreading anything.  So, again, thanks.

snippet.textDisplay: I used the link for the clothesline on Amazon and when I received it, I prewashed it but it didn’t survive that washing (the inner core poked through the braid every few inches on the entire line). I had better luck with clothesline from Walmart that was slightly thicker but held up to repeated washing.
snippet.textOriginal: I used the link for the clothesline on Amazon and when I received it, I prewashed it but it didn’t survive that washing (the inner core poked through the braid every few inches on the entire line). I had better luck with clothesline from Walmart that was slightly thicker but held up to repeated washing.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hardware stores have blackwire that is the same as gardening wire, I think.
I've always kept it on hand for those "chewing gum and baling wire" emergencies that come up.
It's cheap, durable and holds a bent shape the best!
snippet.textOriginal:
Hardware stores have blackwire that is the same as gardening wire, I think.
I've always kept it on hand for those "chewing gum and baling wire" emergencies that come up.
It's cheap, durable and holds a bent shape the best!

snippet.textDisplay:
This is by far the best (& easiest) mask tutorial I’ve seen yet. Sent masks I was able to purchase to my daughter-in-law in NC who is a nurse but I’ll definitely be making these. (I’m a “mender” not a seamstress but even I can follow these instructions.) Thanks for all you’re doing. Everyone on the front lines are in my thoughts and prayers. 🙏🏻 🤗
#kindnessmatters
PS: What do you suggest to use as the filter?
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: To seal the end of the cord:  If you are using nylon cord, melt the end by just barely touching it in a flame n dab onto something heat resistant to stop further melting. Don't BURN yourself but its will get over the fluffy end, that could continue to fray or soak up stuff in the environment.
snippet.textOriginal: To seal the end of the cord:  If you are using nylon cord, melt the end by just barely touching it in a flame n dab onto something heat resistant to stop further melting. Don't BURN yourself but its will get over the fluffy end, that could continue to fray or soak up stuff in the environment.

snippet.textDisplay: I made a few yesterday for my Husband cause he is still going to work.  I didn't have pipe cleaners or wire for the nosepiece but I had 2 rolls of soft wire ties (foam covered wire) for my tomato plants on my gardening shelf.  Cut the pieces, pulled the foam back at the ends and curled the wire in .  My Husband says that they form great to his face and are comfy!  Happy here!  Thanks for the idea! ~  Michele
snippet.textOriginal: I made a few yesterday for my Husband cause he is still going to work.  I didn't have pipe cleaners or wire for the nosepiece but I had 2 rolls of soft wire ties (foam covered wire) for my tomato plants on my gardening shelf.  Cut the pieces, pulled the foam back at the ends and curled the wire in .  My Husband says that they form great to his face and are comfy!  Happy here!  Thanks for the idea! ~  Michele

snippet.textDisplay:
2020 The year China killed the Easter bunny.
The Black Death originated in China in the early to mid-1300s deaths of up to 75-125 million people
(1957 "Asian flu" 2 million deaths, 1968 "Hong Kong flu"killed an estimated one million and 1977 "Asiatic flu or Russian flu"1 million worldwide ) ALL originated from China.

snippet.textDisplay: Jewelry wire used to make jewelry is also a great alternative! It won't rust and it's comfortable and flexible on the nose. I made my mask right after you came out with the first video and I love it. I'm making masks for my family, friends, and neighbors now. This mask design is great, because any one person can wear it with the long cord option. That's one thing that I loved about your design. Secondly, this design doesn't leave any gaps on the sides and I found a lot of other designs ran into that problem. Also, this is an easy sew job. Pleats can become annoying when sewing. So, thank you very much for the time you put into making the first video and also, following up. The only thing I would suggest to everyone is to probably make a slightly larger size for men. Maybe a 11x9 size.
snippet.textOriginal: Jewelry wire used to make jewelry is also a great alternative! It won't rust and it's comfortable and flexible on the nose. I made my mask right after you came out with the first video and I love it. I'm making masks for my family, friends, and neighbors now. This mask design is great, because any one person can wear it with the long cord option. That's one thing that I loved about your design. Secondly, this design doesn't leave any gaps on the sides and I found a lot of other designs ran into that problem. Also, this is an easy sew job. Pleats can become annoying when sewing. So, thank you very much for the time you put into making the first video and also, following up. The only thing I would suggest to everyone is to probably make a slightly larger size for men. Maybe a 11x9 size.

snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you so much, esp face mask becomes a scarcity. Before trying to make one for my mother, it would be great if you can answer some questions:
1. Would the coated wire gets rusty after washing a few times?
2. What material would you recommend to use as filter that's easy to find in crafting stores like Michael's or hobby lobby?
3. What heat setting for it to be dried in dryer? (Or if you recommend to just hang it until dry?)

Many thanks.
snippet.textOriginal:
Thank you so much, esp face mask becomes a scarcity. Before trying to make one for my mother, it would be great if you can answer some questions:
1. Would the coated wire gets rusty after washing a few times? 
2. What material would you recommend to use as filter that's easy to find in crafting stores like Michael's or hobby lobby?
3. What heat setting for it to be dried in dryer? (Or if you recommend to just hang it until dry?)

Many thanks.

snippet.textDisplay: I have to tie the mask at the bottom and in the front, due to limited range of motion in my left shoulder. I put the closed end of the tie over my ears and around the back of my head. Then I bring the two open ends of the tie around the back of my neck and around to the front, so I don't have to reach around my neck to tie it. This seems to be an alternative that works fairly well. I don't tie it very tight in the front. Wouldn't want to choke myself. Ha
snippet.textOriginal: I have to tie the mask at the bottom and in the front, due to limited range of motion in my left shoulder. I put the closed end of the tie over my ears and around the back of my head. Then I bring the two open ends of the tie around the back of my neck and around to the front, so I don't have to reach around my neck to tie it. This seems to be an alternative that works fairly well. I don't tie it very tight in the front. Wouldn't want to choke myself. Ha

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you for all that you do.  A true super hero!  Not only a nurse but a seamstress as well. So, after the medical staff wear these the hospitals, fire departments and police departments etc, can them wash them for ya'll to reuse?  If so, that is the best!   I know a bit about sewing but it's not high on my list of things that I can do...but I can do this one!  What I don't have, is a stash of material.  Are the fabric shops open? I have been inside for weeks now.   Or can I purchase on Amazon or where????  Thanks again!

snippet.textDisplay: I'm not really adept with my sewing machine, but this looked like something even I could do. Made four and they turned out great! I used 54" shoe strings, and we are using Shop Towels folded in fourths for the filter. I'm not down to five minutes yet, but someone with sewing experience could do it! Thank you for this making this video with such clear instructions!
snippet.textOriginal: I'm not really adept with my sewing machine, but this looked like something even I could do. Made four and they turned out great! I used 54" shoe strings, and we are using Shop Towels folded in fourths for the filter. I'm not down to five minutes yet, but someone with sewing experience could do it! Thank you for this making this video with such clear instructions!

snippet.textDisplay: I was excited to try this pattern but the mask puckers on the sides and bottom. It was 100% cotton. It didn't seem too thick. Any thoughts?
snippet.textOriginal: I was excited to try this pattern but the mask puckers on the sides and bottom. It was 100% cotton. It didn't seem too thick. Any thoughts?

snippet.textDisplay:
Here are Written Instructions - Notes from the video (modify as you choose:-)


FABRIC CUTTING INSTRUCTIONS:

(2) pieces of fabric for the interior filter pocket cut
10” long x 8” high (youth size 9x7)

(1) piece of fabric for the exterior of the mask cut 10”
long x 8” high (youth size 9x7)

**make sure you wash, dry and iron your fabric pieces
BEFORE cutting**

piece of synthetic cotton clothesline 3/16 in cut to 50-60”
(the longer it is the more adjustable the fit)

Use 100% Cotton Fabric

Tie a knot on each end of clothesline material; trim
Cut fabric and place interior pieces right sides together
of interior material
Fold lengthwise to form a crease/find center
Lay the ruler on the crease and draw a 3” line from each side
Sew down the lines from each side, backstitch start/finish
Fold up one side of the fabric and press in place (wrong
sides will be together)
Flip fabric over and repeat. (you now have an opening in
the fabric for an insert/filter
Topstitch down the side of the seam to reinforce the
pocket (do this on both sides)
Take exterior piece of fabric front side up; lay the
interior piece on top of it
Stitch around the perimeter with a ¼ inch seam;
Modification: angle the stitch on the corner to create a soft corner
Clip corners to take off the point (unless you sewed an angle on the corner)
Turn inside out through filter pocket; use pencil to
extend; press
With filter pocket side facing up fold up each side (long side) ¾ inch;
press
Pin and Sew the seams
7” piece of hardware wire (or metal clasp)
Bend ends of the wire over twice to keep ends from
poking through and put into the mask through the opening. Place at top of mask
Stitch across the top of the mask to encase the wire.  Be sure to not stitch on the wire to avoid
breaking your needle. Stop before encasing for cord.
Use a safety pin to thread the cord through the side
channels starting at the top of the mask.  (modification)
The cord will finish on the other side of the top of the mask and
voila...complete.

snippet.textDisplay: Seems like a great design, but I have a question about where the filter opening falls on the face. Is it across the mouth or nose? If so, then a filter would be essential when using this mask because the filter opening basically makes this mask one layer of fabric where the opening is. The microscopic size of the virus can get through even a sliver of an opening, and I’ve read that one layer of fabric won’t protect much.
snippet.textOriginal: Seems like a great design, but I have a question about where the filter opening falls on the face. Is it across the mouth or nose? If so, then a filter would be essential when using this mask because the filter opening basically makes this mask one layer of fabric where the opening is. snippet.textDisplay: * * Please Note: If you're making these for donation to medical staff, you may want to consider adding an extra 10" to the cord, so it's 70" long (rather than 60") for those people who have big heads like I do. Please consider updating your instructions so that the cord is 70" long. Also, something else that I think would be great to see in your description / written instructions: Make a double knot at the end of each cord, so that when they're placed in the washer, the cord will hopefully not slide out, because it can be tricky to get them back in. Thank you.
snippet.textOriginal: * * Please Note: If you're making these for donation to medical staff, you may want to consider adding an extra 10" to the cord, so it's 70" long (rather than 60") for those people who have big heads like I do.  Please consider updating your instructions so that the cord is 70" long.  Also, something else that I think would be great to see in your description / written instructions: Make a *double* knot at the end of each cord, so that when they're placed in the washer, the cord will hopefully not slide out, because it can be tricky to get them back in. Thank you.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm about ready to make my first mask using your pattern and tutorial.  The outside print I'm using has a directional pattern so I had to rewatch to make sure I cut it out right. In case anyone else has the same question, the 10" side will be the finished horizontal side and the filter pocket also runs horizontal.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm about ready to make my first mask using your pattern and tutorial.  The outside print I'm using has a directional pattern so I had to rewatch to make sure I cut it out right. In case anyone else has the same question, the 10" side will be the finished horizontal side and the filter pocket also runs horizontal.

snippet.textDisplay: I've tried 4 other mask styles and this is the easiest one to make assembly line style for friends, and the fit is better than the ones with pleats (and my sewing machine likes it more). I used t-shirt yarn I had already made for another project for the ties.
snippet.textOriginal: I've tried 4 other mask styles and this is the easiest one to make assembly line style for friends, and the fit is better than the ones with pleats (and my sewing machine likes it more). I used t-shirt yarn I had already made for another project for the ties.

snippet.textDisplay: I haven't sewn since I was in middle school and it was easy enough for me follow and successfully crank out some masks.  As a healthcare provider, this is the favorite mask type I have worn thus far comfort wise and coverage widse; love that it can be worn over N95 as we are having to re-use.  The only modifications I made were to increase the size to 8 1/2" x 11" (standard sheet of paper) and I did a wide zigzag stitch to encase a pipecleaner (I'm using 6" length so I can get two nosepieces out of one pipecleaner).  Thank you!!!!!
snippet.textOriginal: I haven't sewn since I was in middle school and it was easy enough for me follow and successfully crank out some masks.  As a healthcare provider, this is the favorite mask type I have worn thus far comfort wise and coverage widse; love that it can be worn over N95 as we are having to re-use.  The only modifications I made were to increase the size to 8 1/2" x 11" (standard sheet of paper) and I did a wide zigzag stitch to encase a pipecleaner (I'm using 6" length so I can get two nosepieces out of one pipecleaner).  Thank you!!!!!
